caseStudy.title: Optum Bank: HSA Reimbursement Redesign
caseStudy.subtitle: Redesigned HSA reimbursement feature, improving task completion from 1.1% to 30% and reducing support calls by 30% for 450K users

overview.title: Project Overview
keyPoints: The HSA reimbursement feature had a 98.9% abandonment rate with only 1.1% completionâ€”lowest performing feature in platform
Average completion time was 18 minutes (industry standard is 5-7 minutes)
Support calls related to reimbursement were high and costly
Users struggled with form complexity and mobile experience
challenges: Generic error messages with no guidance
Four distinct user types with conflicting needs
Legacy systems and OCR processing constraints
overview.context: Before my redesign, users struggled with a complex reimbursement process that was manual, error-prone, and inflexible. As Lead UX Designer, I worked with cross-functional teams to design an automated, intelligent system that transformed the user experience.

research.title: Research & Discovery
research.constraints: Healthcare privacy restrictions prevented traditional usability testing

dataAnalysis: 6 months of analytics data identifying 12 drop-off points
800+ customer service transcripts categorized by issue type
Technical system mapping across 3 backend systems
Heuristic evaluation using healthcare UX principles
userResearch: Process mapping sessions with customer service representatives
Analysis of recorded support call patterns
Cross-functional workshops with product, engineering, and compliance teams

keyInsights.mentalModelMismatch: Users thought of expenses by event ('my dentist visit') while system organized by tax category ('preventive care')

digitalNatives.behavior: Abandoned after first failure, expected app-like experience

traditionalPlanners.behavior: Wanted documentation and thorough review process

assistedUsers.behavior: Needed simplified workflows and guided assistance

design.title: Design Strategy
design.approach: Multi-path solutions to serve diverse user needs
keyStrategies: Reframed compliance requirements as trust-building opportunities
Created fundamentally different approaches for different user types
Implemented progressive disclosure for complex workflows

solutions.smartCapture: OCR technology to automatically extract receipt data
solutions.progressiveWorkflow: Multi-step process with clear progress indicators
solutions.contextualHelp: Just-in-time guidance based on user actions
solutions.errorPrevention: Proactive validation and clear error messaging

technical.title: Technical Implementation
architecture: React Native for cross-platform mobile experience
AWS OCR for automated receipt processing
PostgreSQL for data storage and audit trails
features: Automated receipt capture and data extraction

results.title: Results & Impact

businessImpact.operationalEfficiency: Automated workflows dramatically reduced manual processing and support burden
businessImpact.customerSatisfaction: Improved self-service capabilities led to higher platform engagement
businessImpact.scalability: System now handles increased transaction volume without additional support resources
businessImpact.compliance: Enhanced documentation and audit trails improved regulatory adherence

keyLearnings: Regulation as Feature: Reframed compliance requirements as trust-building opportunities
Multi-Path Solutions: Diverse user needs required fundamentally different approaches
Constraints Drive Innovation: Privacy and regulatory limitations led to creative research methods
Mobile-First Impact: Mobile optimization had disproportionate impact on overall success

commonQuestions.What was the main problem?: When I joined this project, the HSA reimbursement feature had a devastating 98.9% abandonment rate - only 1 in 90 users could complete their submissions! Users were struggling with scattered forms, generic error messages, and inconsistent experiences across devices.
commonQuestions.How did you research this?: I had to get creative due to healthcare privacy restrictions. I conducted a 7-week research phase, analyzing 6 months of analytics data and over 800 customer service transcripts, plus stakeholder interviews and process mapping sessions with the support team.
commonQuestions.What were the key insights?: My biggest 'aha moment' was discovering this massive mental model mismatch - users thought about expenses by event like 'my dentist visit' while our system organized by tax category like 'preventive care'. I also identified four very distinct user types with completely different needs.
commonQuestions.What was your design approach?: I realized I needed fundamentally different approaches for different user types. I implemented multi-path solutions, reframed compliance requirements as trust-building opportunities, and used constraints to drive innovation. My strategy focused on progressive disclosure for complex workflows.
commonQuestions.What technology did you use?: I chose React Native for cross-platform mobile experience, Node.js for the backend, AWS OCR for automated receipt processing, and PostgreSQL for data storage with comprehensive audit trails. The OCR was key to eliminating manual data entry.
commonQuestions.What were the results?: I'm really proud of what we achieved! Task completion went from 1.1% to 30% - that's a 27x improvement. We cut completion time from 18 to 10 minutes, improved mobile completion from 0.3% to 18%, and reduced support calls by 30%, saving about $800K annually in support costs.
commonQuestions.What did you learn?: This project taught me to treat regulation as a feature rather than constraint, that diverse user needs require fundamentally different approaches, that constraints can drive innovation, and that mobile optimization had disproportionate impact on overall success.
